Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Reconstructing Deglacial and Holocene Climate Variability in Southeast Asia Using Speleothems and Isotope-Enabled Model Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Asian Monsoon system is an important component of the global climate system that plays a major role in the transport of heat and moisture from the tropics to higher latitudes. Even small variations in the strength and/or timing of seasonal rainfall can have significant impacts on the billions of people living within the Asian monsoon domain, yet climate model projections of future monsoon changes still remain uncertain. While paleoclimate records have significantly advanced our understanding of summer monsoon variability in some regions, we still know very little about the range and mechanisms of monsoon variability in Southeast Asia.

This research, a collaborative effort between scientists from the University of California, Irvine and William Patterson College of New Jersey, will generate high-resolution speleothem (cave calcite deposit) records of past hydroclimate variability over the last 20,000 years from Laos, a key site at the interface between the Indian and East Asian monsoon systems. The new oxygen isotope records will document changes in Southeast Asian monsoon strength on sub-decadal to orbital timescales, filling in a key spatial and temporal gap in the paleoclimate record of the tropics. Through integrating paleoclimate proxy data, instrumental climate data, and climate model analyses, the project will address three main questions: (1) How has Southeast Asian monsoon intensity varied over the past 20,000 years in response to orbital forcing, millennial-scale abrupt climate events, and interannual to multi-decadal climate modes?; (2) What are the mechanisms that control precipitation and speleothem oxygen isotopes on interannual to orbital timescales in Laos?; and (3) How do the Laos speleothem records relate to broader spatial and temporal patterns of past climate variability in the tropical Indo-Pacific, the Asian monsoon region, and high latitudes? In addition to the scientific outcomes, this project will provide research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students and will be incorporated in outreach efforts aimed at improving the participation of underrepresented groups in the geosciences. For instance, a hands-on field and laboratory exercise on paleoclimate, climate change, and native culture will be developed for the NSF funded American Indian Summer Institute in Earth System Science held at the University of California, Irvine each summer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Asian Monsoon (AM) system is an important component of the global climate system that plays a major role in the transport of heat and moisture from the tropics to higher latitudes.  Even small variations in the strength and timing of seasonal rainfall can have significant impacts on the billions of people living within the AM domain, yet general circulation model projections of future regional-scale hydrologic change still remain uncertain, hampering efforts to conduct appropriate planning. Despite significant advances in our understanding of tropical Indo-Pacific and monsoon paleoclimate variability on orbital to millennial timescales, we still know very little about the range and mechanisms of variability in the Southeast Asian monsoon (SEAM) region. To address this need, we have developed new high-resolution speleothem stable isotope [i.e. oxygen (δ18O) and carbon (δ13C)], trace element, and petrographic records from Tham Doun Mai (TM) Cave, Laos. The  primary objectives of this project were to determine:  (1) How the Southeast Asian monsoon intensity has varied over the Late Pleistocene-Holocene in response to orbital forcing, millennial scale abrupt climate events, and interannual to multi-decadal climate modes, (2) The primary controls on the oxygen isotopic composition (δ18O) of precipitation and speleothem calcite in Laos through analysis of isotope-enabled general circulation model (GCM) simulations (IsoGSM and GISS ModelE) and forward-modeling of speleothem δ18O, (3) How the Laos speleothem records relate to broader spatial and temporal patterns of past climate variability in the tropical Indo-Pacific, the Asian monsoon region, and high-latitudes. 

We conducted 2 field trips in 2015 and 2017 to conduct cave monitoring work to improve proxy interpretation, and have developed 8 overlapping, speleothem stable isotope records spanning the last 46 kyr.  The records consist of over 6,000 stable isotope analyses and are constrained by >120 U-Th dates.  A trace element record has also been developed via HR-ICPMS for one particularly well-dated stalagmite that spans the last 37.7 kyr. Synchrotron Sr measurements and speleothem micro-fabric analyses on this speleothem lend further support to our proxy interpretation.  In addition to our long decadal resolution record, we have constructed two ~2 year resolution records spanning the last 2,000 years.   Our results highlight the utility of a multi-proxy approach, wherein δ18O records from this region are reflective of large-scale monsoon intensity and upstream rainout, whereas δ13C and trace element ratios are useful proxies for local water balance. 

Our analysis of the IsoGSM model simulated precipitation δ18O and instrumental climate data (Yang et al., 2016) have advanced our understanding of the controls on isotopic variability in SEAM precipitation and paleoclimate archives.  A primary outcome from this work is that variations in monsoon intensity and upstream rainout, which have been recently invoked to explain coherent speleothem δ18O variability on orbital and millennial timescales, also operate over shorter, interannual timescales.  Our speleothem δ18O records are remarkably similar to other Asian speleothem records, with the δ18O showing a precessional signal and clear δ18O increases (i.e. weaker monsoon) during various North Atlantic cold events (i.e. Heinrich Stadial events and the Younger Dryas). The strong similarity of these records across the broad Asian monsoon region support the hypothesis that variations in upstream rainout and Indian monsoon strength are the dominant mechanism precipitation δ18O variability. In contrast to δ18O, TM speleothem δ13C, trace elements, and crystal fabric are more likely reflective of local hydroclimate.  The δ13C record shows large positive excursions during these North Atlantic cold events, suggesting dry conditions. Interestingly, the TM δ13C values diverge from δ18O during the early Holocene (~8-10,000 years ago) insolation maxima, suggesting that dry conditions in SE Asia were synchronous with increased Asian Monsoon intensity; this interpretation is further supported by speleothem greyscale measurements, which reflect internal porosity mainly related to infiltration. Model analyses conducted with the isotope-enabled GISS Model E suggest dry conditions in SE Asia during insolation maxima may arise from decreased low-level moisture convergence over the Indo-China Peninsula as precipitation over India and East Asia increases, effectively drawing away moisture from our study site. 

This project has provided training for four female undergraduate students and four PhD students (2 female, 2 male), one of whom completed her PhD in 2016. Furthermore, this work was presented to student participants in the 2015-2017 American Indian Summer Institute in Earth System Science (NSF Funded OEDG Project to PI Johnson). The PI, a Native American female, was interviewed about this research for Earth Magazine’s “Down to Earth” feature in February 2017. Finally, this work has strengthened international relationships with Laos partners in the Middle Mekong Archaeology Project and is contributing to ongoing debates about the role that Mid- to-Late Holocene climate changes played in the human history of Southeast Asia.  This work has, thus far, resulted in 1 publication (Yang et al., 2016), 1 PhD thesis (Yang et al., 2016), and 13 conference abstracts.
